Legal_Issue: Does Chehade meet the residency requirement under s. 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act despite being absent for business?
Application_Facts: Chehade was absent for 454 days due to business in the United Arab Emirates; maintained family ties and some formal connections but did not centralize his mode of living in Canada.
Court_Ruling: Appeal dismissed; Chehade remains ineligible for citizenship
Defendant_Behavior: Prolonged absence from Canada for business purposes without sufficient re-establishment of residential ties
Grounds_for_Claim: Failure to meet minimum physical presence requirement for citizenship
Legal_Standard: Applicant must have at least three years of residence in Canada within four years preceding application
Assessment_Factor: Centralization of mode of living in Canada, degree of Canadianization
Procedural_Issue: Admissibility and consideration of new evidence on appeal
Evidence_Used: Duration of absences, nature of business activities abroad, maintenance of family and formal ties in Canada
Application_Basis: Physical presence and residential connection to Canada
Evidence_Assessed: 454 days of absence, continued family residence in Canada, lack of centralized life in Canada
Governing_Rule: Three-year physical residence requirement within four years prior to application
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient proof of centralizing life in Canada during period of absence
Cause_Description: Chehade's citizenship application was denied due to insufficient residency
Evidence_Handling: New evidence reviewed by judge on appeal
Evidence_Issues: Weight given to non-residential connections versus actual physical presence
Evidence_Assessment: Judge reviewed facts and legal precedents
Decision_Rationale: Chehade did not demonstrate that he centralized his mode of living in Canada
Country_of_Origin: United Arab Emirates (location of business activities)
Evidentiary_Issues: Reliance on circumstantial indicators of residency rather than physical presence
Legal_Standard_Applied: Objective assessment of residence based on factual permanence and integration
